awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019: What you eat affects the enemies that eat you: Examining the relationship between diet and natural enemies
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.  This study examines how the diet of an animal can help it survive attacks from other animals.  The Fellow studies the fall webworm, a caterpillar that eats the leaves of different trees.  Fall webworms are attacked by parasitic insects that lay their eggs inside the caterpillar and use it as a host.  The caterpillar's immune system can help defend against these parasitic insects, but the strength of the immune system can be affected by the caterpillar's diet.  The Fellow uses experiments and field surveys in Colorado to understand whether different trees increase the immunity of the fall webworm against wasp attacks.  The survival of insects, like many animals, is dependent on the plants in their habitat.  As changes in climate transform many plant communities, insects are likely to be affected too. This study will increase understanding of how plant-insect interactions might change if major climatic events drastically modify plant communities.  In addition, the Fellow works closely with youth from underrepresented minority students from urban areas in Denver.  Students will participate in wildlife surveys, which increase awareness of wildlife. The fellow will also promote opportunities for mentorship and guidance by creating an online network of biologists from minority backgrounds who will advise high school students. 

For widely distributed animals, the relative importance of diet and natural enemies can vary depending on location and composition of ecological communities.  The Fellow will use genomics to identify and quantify the diversity of parasitic insects attacking fall webworm across its range in Colorado. Next, the Fellow will use lab experiments to measure the relationship between diet and the nutrient quality of fall webworms.  Finally, the Fellow will manipulate the caterpillar's diet to examine how different tree species impact the caterpillar's ability to launch immune defenses against parasitic insects.  This research includes two approaches to increase interactions with nature among underrepresented minority students in urban public schools. First, the Fellow will use an experiential learning model to create interactive out-of-school learning opportunities for middle school students. Second, the Fellow will build an online network of professional biologists who agree to be mentors for high school students with interests in biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In nature, animals must find food while also avoid becoming food.  Insects have survived for millions of years even though they are eaten by other animals, which means that they have found ways to get food while escaping enemies.  However, some insects eat only a few specific items, while other insects eat many different types of food.  So, what determines the diversity of an insect?s diet?  As an ecologist and NSF Postdoctoral Fellow, I studied whether an insect?s diet protects the insect from an enemy.  Some of the most common insect enemies are other insects, many of which attack and lay their eggs inside a host that eventually dies from the attack.  The host insect can defend itself through its immune system, which can be enhanced or weakened by the insect?s diet.  Therefore, the diets of an insect might be shaped by the threat it faces from its enemies. To answer this question, I studied the fall webworm caterpillars in Colorado where they eat over 10 different types of plants.  The fall webworm caterpillars are attacked by parasitic wasps and parasitic flies that use the caterpillars as a host.  My first goal was to identify the diversity of fall webworm enemies in Colorado, and I found that fall webworm caterpillars are attacked by at least 10 species of parasitic wasps and 4 species of parasitic flies.  Next, I conducted an experiment to determine if different plant diets affect the fall webworm caterpillar?s ability to defend against a parasitic wasp.  I found that apple tree leaves were the worst diet because the caterpillars grew the smallest, and their immune system was the weakest at defending against the parasitic wasp.  The next step is to calculate if the threat of parasitism is greater in some parts of Colorado, and if so, do the fall webworms eat specific plants in these regions.  I suspect that when the enemy threat is low, fall webworms might have a more diverse diet, including apple.  However, if the enemy pressure is high, then perhaps the fall webworms eat only plants that are beneficial to their immune defenses against enemies.

Biology has traditionally lacked racial diversity because of many factors, but I sought to address two of these factors.  First, many children from minority racial backgrounds fail to have hands-on experiences with nature that could ignite a curiosity about biology.  Second, there are few non-white scientists who serve as role models for underrepresented minority children.  As part of my commitment to broadening racial and cultural representation in biology, in 2019 I created Biology for Underrepresented Groups in Science (BUGS: https://bugseducation.wixsite.com/bugs), an organization that creates hands-on interactions with live animals in Denver K-12 public schools with high proportions of minority students on free and reduced lunch programs.  In 2019, BUGS had a booth at a Denver area STEM fair where we hosted over 50 students and parents who interacted with our reptiles, amphibians, and museum specimens.  During these opportunities to interact with animals, students were more likely to ask questions and increase their curiosity about nature.  In addition to animal interactions in the classroom, I was working on collaborations with local outdoor organizations who could help me lead urban nature surveys in Denver city parks.  These activities were meant to enhance urban youth?s appreciation for the wildlife in their backyard and show them that valuable nature occurs in cities. 

I began a collaboration with a high school with a high majority Hispanic demographic that was eager for problem-based learning projects.  My goal was to partner with students in an 11th grade class to develop a website with contact information of biologists who represent African American, Hispanic, and other minority groups that have low representation in biology.  This website, called ?A Scientist Like Me?, would be resource for high school students who seek mentors with similar cultural backgrounds.  ?A Scientist Like Me? was to be the first step in the career of a student who is curious about biology, and who feels more comfortable seeking guidance from scientists they find more relatable.

My progress on BUGs and ?A Scientist Like Me? was impaired by school closures during the pandemic, but I continue to build relationships with Denver city K-12 schools.  Although I made minimal progress on my projects with K-12 schools, I was successful at mentoring 11 female undergraduate students and one female postbaccalaureate, all of whom were research assistants on my NSF project.  Of those 11 female research assistants, two are from minority backgrounds and both are pursuing either graduate school or a career in life sciences.  The NSF postdoctoral fellowship enabled me to start projects that I am confident will help increase diversity in biology.  As a professor, I am now eager to continue what I started and continue to move my projects closer to their successful outcomes.


Last Modified: 07/11/2022
Modified by: Dhaval Vyas
